Miudo
Tha dance of the ducks

You have no idea what you are asking for...

We fought hard to get this stupid cap removed eons ago. Thanks to that you managed to be on the legendary town and most of the events you speak of.

People want to play with their friends. Its just stupid to block them from doing it.

Add the meta-cap now and more than half of the dedicated player-base will go MiA. Sure some other players will appear and will learn to deal with it.

What you want is actually a proper Leaderboard system.

MT was both right and wrong when they created the Leaderboards.

They were right because, once you get the hang of how the game works, you want to pit against other players/groups to see who is the best.

They were wrong because it focused the good/decent players and made random towns quality drop a lot... leading to mass-quitting. All the heroes went to compete and no one was left to attend to them newbies.

They tried to fix this with the meta-cap, but this messed with something that most players want: to have fun with their friends.

Hence, it was removed and thank Corvuness, it is still lifted. It is what kept this game alive, well, more like un-dead, for quite some time.

It would be great to have a way to play both modes. In a way that one won't hurt the other and both won't hurt the game. Sadly Motion Twin's lazy approach turned this into an arena where both sides point fingers at each other claiming that they are the cause of the game to be like this.
On november 20, 2016
yungching
Home Depot Regular

Disclaimer: Brainstorming is fun. buzzard is awesome but it is quite obvious the devs don't care enough to listen to suggestions, so it is only empty talk. If you don't like it or I'm too longwinded, don't read it
But yeah this discussion has been had before, and the things I'm going to say in this post I believe I have already written before too. But the game is a stagnant can of water, therefore the discourse will also always swirl around the little pool of water there is

I've been trying to think of a way this problem could be balanced out. The problem is, implementing any kind of solution would demand judgment criteria on what is meta play and what is not.

1. The idea of separate leaderboards is an old one. But how can it be effectively implemented with care that there is no abuse? And what would the limit be? Even an MMJ can throw all randoms off the leaderboards, simply because a big part of MMJ players are also meta players, whether or not they chose to be together. (Ideally an event like the MMJ should have its own internal ranking system, like CotT and other events have.) What about half-metas or just fun towns?

I'm thinking a system like that of the SDF on Mush would be interesting. If a leaderboard was set up for meta towns only, metas/groups would probably have to sign up "officially" so that they are recognised. If this happens, the "SDF" team could comprise of one or two leaders from each meta, as well as a couple known random-town-players, to ensure fair judgment etc.

Another way to do it could be that each time a group of more than 5 decide to play together, they would have to let the "SDF" know of their venture, and it would be up to the team to categorise what leaderboard the town should go under.

I am aware that the effort that has to be put into such kind of work is tremendous and unrewarding for the most part, and even though I know some players would volunteer to do this kind of thing, I feel bad for even suggesting an idea that could give them such a burden lol. Not to mention it is often hard to find replacements for quitting dedicated members.

2. Another old idea, I believe, was to have a Private town leaderboard. However since the settings of a P. town can be tweaked, it would make the attempts somewhat less random, perhaps even "fairer". But an agreement would have to be made to have the same settings for all ranking attempts. (I'm thinking they could revote for different settings each season to make it more interesting?) Again, to resolve the drama that is bound to happen (just look at our past ), a team of judges would still be needed in case people are not satisfied with just grabbing the P. town ranking distinctions and want to also get the random town ones This could be resolved with a meta-cap on random towns I guess, but we'd have to bring back the multiple-towns-filling-at-the-same-time thing.

An advantage of this idea could be that for crazy distinction collectors, it would be an incentive to cooperate in random towns too. We need this desperately. Whether or not we get separate leaderboards, we need to find incentive for good players to play well in random towns too, at least on occasion. (The way the community has tried to do this is by organising Spiritual Guide contests, which is awesome, but not a permanent solution?)

3. We've also suggested alternating seasons between metacap and non-metacap before. And matsuuu is right about 3 month seasons. For this to work, leaderboard renewal has to be much more frequent or some players would leave (while waiting for non-cap season) and never come back. It would be interesting if each new update (not that there are any these days) could be split into half, the first half without meta-cap so that the metas are also somewhat handicapped by the fact that they have to adapt to new mechanics, and the second half with cap so that once good players have learned to deal with the new things, they can't exploit it forever There is also good reason to do it the other way, ie. meta-cap first, then no cap. Because this would mean meta players are forced to figure the new mechanics out together with other random players and develop techniques in random towns to use in the next half of the season. This has the potential to make random towns better prepared too, and maybe actually have a chance at ranking despite no cap.

- - - - - - - - -
On another note, I'm surprised about Miudo's positive view of metas. For some reason I had the impression that you'd come to hate them

Anyway, this
Miudo
It would be great to have a way to play both modes. In a way that one won't hurt the other and both won't hurt the game. Sadly Motion Twin's lazy approach turned this into an arena where both sides point fingers at each other claiming that they are the cause of the game to be like this. is the best paragraph I've read from you for a while

And I'll stop here even though I just remembered more things to say because I know I've already scared off a bunch of people with Huge Wall of Text and the others are begging me to stop .

that's the point. the WF discussions are made by 90% of random town players. even though meta players represent the wider amount of active/constant players.I beg to differ :p

The current top two threads in this forum (Not sure about the other forums, don't have the habit of reading them) are dominated by meta players. Even if you count former meta players that are now random town players, it is still quite clear. most regular meta folks are veterans that won't waste time chatting or on boring long discussions. Someone has to participate in the forums It would be distressingly quiet and discouraging if everyone kept to their own group chats. (These days, even those are dead) Imho, participating in discussions is a way of keeping the game alive too :p

they always have contributed to nearly all significant stuff such as founding, researching, exploring game aspects, making events, embracing new players and keeping them around, etc.This is true, but I have to say that the last two can't happen if
they just play, hang out occasionally on their group chats and keep the game existing by buying hero days
I am at the end of a random town. The main players that cooperated and helped each other out were random town players. The other players I recognised from metas stayed quiet throughout the duration of the town (I know it's not necessarily on purpose, but still).

Meta hero players definitely help keep the gave alive by paying, but by sticking solely to meta towns they can also contribute to the killing of the player base. This is in fact what the 'boring' discussion is about.

I believe in playing to the fullest of my ability whether it is a random or a meta town. Not everyone has the time and the will to do this, but a balance would still be nice. The truth is that if MT isn't willing to do anything to keep players coming and staying, we have to do it on our own. To some extent, random town players keep the game alive by providing a less horrible introduction to the game (after which most move on to meta towns).

I was initially posting because it's fun for me, but now I actually think it is an important discussion. If meta players could be convinced or given the incentive to play random towns actively, it definitely wouldn't hurt the game.

I love meta towns myself, and if I bought Hero Days (which are quite expensive in my country's currency) like I have been wanting to for a long time, I admit I might be reluctant to spend them on random towns. The thing is, this is only true because it is hard to get meta friends to jump into random towns themselves, and random towns can feel like a waste of hero days when the other 39 players don't care about the town at all. Not to mention trying to care about and convince those players that there is more to the game is really tiring to do if alone. However, with even just a coalition of 5, interesting things can be done.

Sigh, I suck at summarising my thoughts lol. If it's too long, don't read :p Anyway, I may not be the best judge, I have after all only been back for 2 weeks. My opinion is not the most important either, as I simply can't play die2nite regularly enough to even follow my own advice. These are just my two cents, as a former full-time player and still full-time (verbal) supporter of the game. I admit that I am using this thread as a platform to let out some of the thoughts that I've been having, and I admit that if you cut my posts into portions and posted one each day I could keep the thread alive on my own However, no one is obliged to read them and I am posting because someone else said something to trigger me :p If the thread is boring it'll die on it's own
I promise to refrain from doing any other post longer than the combined length of all the posts since my last

ofc the prizes are a fair and deserved outcome, but they mean nothing compared to the memorable moments and friend I gathered on organized playing.

matsuuu, you're making a very distorted concept about meta players based on biased opinions. If you want to know meta players, get to know them, don't take words from others.

I have played dozens of small/random towns ever since I started. I never stopped playing them, even using hero days whilst on meta breaks. We had a common practice of posting on meta-town PMs asking people to join us on random towns on the very day we die. We ALWAYS went there to help newbies, we posted tutorial and FAQ threads, we created town chat and insistently invited people to join there and talk/learn/chit-chat, anything. We organized several events such the one the Inn made by the end of S9 or 10 when we splitted the meta on several coalitions of 5 players, jumping one coa on a different town to teach new players. We had a Spiritual Guide counter where the winner coa would be the one with more points considering SG, days lived, newbies gotten in chat, etc. Joanne and Dream and Miudo also organized and hosted many, many, many of such events . Yes, Miudo IS a meta player no matter how much he criticizes the thing. He runs (or ran) a resident meta which is no less of a meta for that matter.

So running this raid against meta players and gaming is not just unfair, but incredibly stingy and petty. If not for meta players initiatives this game would be dead and I mean it. And no, we didn't come up with all that using our time and money just to abduct poor innocent new players into our void of evil twisted meta-gaming. We did that to keep the game alive and active. We just invited over the ones that clearly manifested interest on meta-gaming.

Those activities lasted until that update when they messed up small towns completely by removing camping, removing souls/shaman and making the disastrous mechanic that red souls would increase attack. That was the final blow on small towns and any hope to make them interesting since they DO die a lot faster now making it impossible for a new player to get along and understand d2n's basic concepts which takes time. We even had our share of active non-meta players actually doing anything but ranting and self-pitying such as maddonut, blaire and a few others, but everything has a limit, and so is our patience to keep supporting and resilicence to keep insisting on something that never changed, got updated, advertised, etc. After a couple years it gets boring and people just stop swimming. Miudo

Die2nite started with the meta concept already installed and rooted. When MT decided to use the meta-cap here (like they did to Hordes) there was a riot and we managed to remove it. For good.

I'm not against those people, what they achieved, and the meta concept. On the contrary. As you said I was a meta player and I had good times during all my days there. However my start on the meta world was slow. I happened to be in a half-meta town once and I start tasting the meta-ways slowly until a point where I've create my own group.

While true that Hordes already had meta play, that's very much NOT how it started here and I'm sick enough of that line that I'm taking a break from my extreme lurk mode in WF.

All of the original metas started as nothing more than friends (some IRL, some met up in towns here) wanting to continue playing in towns together. My first meta started with a whopping 4 people in my first town. (Oh, and Season 0 was not the same thing as Beta. I missed Beta yet still had quite a few towns in Season 0. You can see as much from my soul and lack of a beta distinction. I missed it by days )

IIRC, there was a ban on Hordes players from playing Die2Nite for a while so that D2N could become its own community with its own ideals. (I may be off because I know there were a few from Hordes that were here, but it wasn't a lot - not by a long shot.)

Metas were never started with the intention of "I'm gonna get #1 and screw everyone else". Each and every one of them started with a desire to play with like minded people and grew from there. Fodgycakes laid down challenge after challenge for everyone else to try to attain. Not because she was trying to win, but because she wanted to see what *could* be done... how far towns could go... how this works.. what happens if... you get the point. The rest of us found that competitive spirit and joined in. It was always friendly and there was a lot of information sharing (though not always everything!).

And an additional note: the revolt against meta cap didn't have nearly as much to do with leaderboard or competition as much as people just wanted to play with their friends.

Anyway, it's semi off topic for the rest of this thread, but there's your short history of metas from someone that actually participated in it from the very start.

Tha dance of the ducks
k0l3For data-gathering-lovers: A good one would be a research on how many and who are the currently active metas. I've been hearing names and initials lately that I've never heard before...

That is actually something that will make you sad and disappointed...

There aren't many new metas. Well, not that we can call them metas, as most of them are one-man bands. e.g: BinxMuldoon's unnamed "meta".

Some metas are always changing names and colors and/or stealing members from other groups (or whole groups from other groups...), so its hard to define it a "new meta". e.g: HIVE, SotA

As for active groups of players, here is some things you can check to spot some of them (the good and the bad):

  • Twinoid Group List. this page will list your groups, but after that it will list the most recent English created groups on Twinoid. Some die2nite coalitions create groups here, you if you check the list now you will see bloo's coalition group there. There's a lot of spam groups there though, so watch where you are clicking.
  • MapViewer and FromDuskTillDawn's Leaderboards are also a source of data regarding groups. MapViewer will list the active towns and you can easily spot where there's probably a group/one-man band. FDTD's Leardboard is also a good source of leads on shady groups mostly. Check the Mystic distinction and you will see some unusual names on the top positions there. We all know that to get this distinction you need at least a bit of coordination...anyway
  • Our 35 slots leaderboards on die2nite soul page allow us to see some other groups playing. Specially those that for some reason don't want to use external sites... which smells fishy.

Lastly, you might want to know if the old metas are still playing, so you might want to take a look at the Meta Collision Checker sheet we made a looong time ago.

THis sheet has the contact of some metas, so you can go to their groups and follow people to their souls and see if they are playing or not. Or just try enter their chat

Tha dance of the ducks

So... if I spend hours buying lots of lottery tickets and then someone else with just one ticket wins I can't cry about it?

The way rankings are now (well, not now that there are no more Seasons...) metas get to compete with randoms for the same leaderboards.

It is obvious that meta towns last longer, but why cant we compete to see who lasts longer with a random environment? That would really prove who are the best players, not who is the best group.

There should be 2 different play options, one truly random and one for competition. Ranking should be present on both. Heroes or long term players or premium users/thingie can play on both. (Ahem, Private Town rankings)

With just one leaderboard and solo/team players competing for the same slow filling towns, the result can only be attrition.

People wanting to play in a meta will lower the quality of random towns. Low quality of random towns = More people complaining about the game. That is a fact.

Conclusion:
- Metas are contributing for this game to have a premature, yet slow, death.
- Using "go play in a meta" solution for whiners is not helping at all
- Random towns will suck and will continue to suck for eternity.
- Players complaining that their "last 2 towns" since they "got back" sucked should be more patient or just quit and go play another thing. Die2nite is not for you.

On january 23, 2018
Miudo
Tha dance of the ducks
wLinkRealistically speaking wouldn't be people less inclined to form metas back in season 1 in the first place if there was no ranking?

Metas would be formed anyway, not because of rankings, but because of the ability and desire to play with friends over and over again. Achieve the rankings or not is a consequence of that.

People already jumped at the same time during Old Towns (before rankings, Season 0, call w/e you like) so that everyone, or most of it, ended up in the same town.

Sure these groups noticed they fared well compared to the complete random experience. Even in a time when we knew so few about this game to come up with advanced tactics.

When they launched the Seasons (and the leaderboards with it) the devs noticed that these groups had the advantage over the true experience of the game, or what they thought to be the true experience of the game.

That's where the meta cap begun. Towns had a limit of coalitions and if one of those groups wanted to be in the same town they would have to tell their members to individually jump themselves to a specific town.

While the cap was producing more random towns, it broke that feeling of "i want to game with my friends!', so we rallied to this cause and pressured MT to lift the cap.

Two seasons later we got our "Independence". Maybe it was here that we went wrong in all this... or maybe MT's approach to the issue was wrong. Who knows, maybe if we settled with the Mega Meta Jump events that started before this period, we might still have the devs around. Hard to say as there are many variables here.

But no, it wasn't because die2nite became competitive that metas were formed, they were here even before they knew it themselves.

You have to remember that this is a game that was born in the french version, we got just a reflection of it. The leaderboards was probably something the french user base requested and it worked for them, while here we turned it into our demise.
